children.name: when you wish that sth had not happened or was not true
unfortunately
children.definition: /ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənɪtli, ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənətli/  use this to show that you wish something had not happened, or you wish something was not true:
examples: thật không may
▪ There’s nothing I can do about it, unfortunately.
Không may là tôi không thể làm gì với nó.
▪ Unfortunately, Dr Cole cannot spend as long with each patient as she would like.
Thật không may, bác sĩ Cole không thể dành thời gian chữa trị lâu hơn cho từng bệnh nhân dù cô rất muốn.
▪ We took some fantastic photos, but unfortunately the film got damaged.
Chúng tôi đã chụp một số bức ảnh tuyệt vời, nhưng tiếc là phim bị hỏng.

children.name: sadly
children.definition: /ˈsædli/  unfortunately - use this to talk about events or situations that are very sad:
examples: thật đáng buồn là
▪ Sadly, this fine old theatre was destroyed by fire in 1993.
Đáng buồn thay, nhà hát cũ đẹp đẽ này đã bị lửa phá hủy vào năm 1993.
▪ Alice was rushed to hospital, but sadly she died two hours later.
Alice đã được đưa đến bệnh viện, nhưng thật đáng buồn cô đã chết hai giờ sau đó.

children.name: it’s a pity
children.definition: /shame A2 spoken say this to show that you feel disappointed or sad about something that has happened:
examples: thật đáng tiếc
▪ It’s a pity about the weather - it was so nice yesterday.
Thật đáng tiếc trời hôm nay không đẹp - ngày hôm qua thật tuyệt vời.
it’s a pity/shame (that)
thật đáng tiếc là
▪ It’s a shame you can’t come with us.
Thật đáng tiếc khi bạn không thể đến với chúng tôi.
what a pity/shame!say this to show that you feel sad or sympathetic about something
thật đáng tiếc!
▪ ‘Janet didn’t get that job.’ ‘Oh, what a pity!’
'Janet đã không nhận được công việc đó.' 'Ôi, thật đáng tiếc!'
a real/terrible shame
thật đáng tiếc
▪ They’ve cut down all those beautiful trees. It’s a terrible shame.
Họ đã chặt tất cả những cây đẹp. Đó là một sự đáng tiếc kinh khủng.

children.name: it’s sad U
children.definition: it’s sad/ɪts ˈsæd/spokenuse this to show that you feel upset about something sad that has happened, and you wish the situation was different:
examples: thật đáng buồn
it’s sad (that)
thật đáng buồn là
▪It’s so sad that your father can’t be here to see this.
Thật buồn khi bố của bạn không thể đến đây để xem điều này.
it’s sad when
thật đáng buồn khi
▪ It’s sad when a marriage breaks up, especially after all those years.
Thật buồn khi một cuộc hôn nhân tan vỡ, đặc biệt là sau những năm tháng đó.
it’s very/terribly sad
thật đáng buồn
▪ The town centre is dying, and most of the shops have closed down. It’s terribly sad.
Trung tâm thị trấn sắp lụi tàn, và hầu hết các cửa hàng đều đóng cửa. Thật đáng buồn.

children.name: too bad
children.definition: /ˌtuː ˈbæd/ especially American use this to say you are disappointed or sad that someone could not do something, or something could not happen:tiếc quá
examples: ▪ ‘Senator Volk’s out of town.’ ‘Too bad! I wanted to meet him and talk about the campaign.’
'Thượng nghị sĩ Volk ra khỏi thị trấn' 'Tiếc quá! Tôi muốn gặp anh ấy và nói về chiến dịch.
too bad (that)
tiếc quá khi
▪ Too bad Dickie isn’t here to enjoy the fun.
Tiếc quá khi Dickie không có ở đây để thưởng thức điều này.
▪ It’s too bad you have to leave, just when we need you most.
Tiếc quá bạn phải rời đi, khi chúng tôi cần bạn nhất.

children.name: it’s unfortunate
children.definition: /ɪts ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənt/ spoken say this when something causes disappointment, suffering or is inconvenient etc: thật không may
examples: ▪ The wedding was lovely. It was just unfortunate about the rain.
it’s unfortunate (that)
▪ It’s unfortunate that you have to travel so far to work.

children.name: more’s the pity U
children.definition: more’s the pity/ˌmɔːʳz ðə ˈpɪti/ British spoken say this when you wish that the fact that you have just mentioned was not true: quả là đáng tiếc
examples: ▪ Now I’m too old to fall in love, more’s the pity.
▪ I’m afraid this car doesn’t belong to me, more’s the pity.

children.name: regrettably
children.definition: /rɪˈgretəbli/  formal use this when you consider the existing situation to be unsatisfactory: thật đáng tiếc là
examples: ▪ Regrettably Jousse’s work has not been translated into English.
Đáng tiếc là tác phẩm của Jousse đã không được dịch sang tiếng Anh.
▪ The poor and disadvantaged will, regrettably, be the ones to suffer as a result of the new law.
Những người nghèo và những người thiệt thòi, đáng tiếc, là những người bị ảnh hưởng bởi luật mới.

children.name: sth that is believed to give you bad luck
unlucky
children.definition: /ʌnˈlʌki/  không may mắn
examples: ▪ I never kill spiders - it’s unlucky.
▪ Why do you want to get married on the 13th?Thirteen is such an unlucky number.
be unlucky to do something
▪ Some people think it’s unlucky to walk under ladders.

children.name: bad luck
children.definition: be/bring /biː, ˌbrɪŋ bæd ˈlʌk/  sth that is bad luck or brings bad luck is believed to make bad things happen:
examples: ▪ It’s supposed to be bad luck to open an umbrella in the house.
▪ For centuries, crows have been thought to bring bad luck.

children.name: sth that you wish had not happened or was not true
unfortunate
children.definition: không may
examples: ▪ Parents are so busy with their careers that they don’t have time to have fun with their children, and that’s unfortunate.
unfortunate circumstances/event/situation etc
▪ ‘It was an unfortunate set of circumstances that no one could have predicted,’ a spokesperson said today.

children.name: regrettable
children.definition: /rɪˈgretəbəl/  formal something that is regrettable makes you feel sorry because it has unpleasant results:đáng tiếc
examples: ▪ ‘This is an unfortunate and extremely regrettable incident,’ the minister told a newspaper.
Bộ trưởng nói với tờ báo: "Đây là một sự việc không may và rất đáng tiếc.
▪ It was decided by the authorities that the building of the dam across the valley was a ‘regrettable necessity’.
Chính quyền quyết định rằng việc xây dựng đập trên thung lũng là một 'điều cần thiết đáng tiếc'.

children.name: when sb is unlucky in a particular situation or at a particular time
unlucky
children.definition: /ʌnˈlʌki/
examples: không may mắn
▪ ‘Were you disappointed with the team’s performance?’ ‘No, not really, I think we were just unlucky.’
be unlucky (enough) to do something
▪ The victims were simply unlucky enough to have been in the restaurant when the gunmen started shooting.
unlucky with
▪ We were unlucky with the weather. It rained almost every day we were on the island.

children.name: unfortunate
children.definition: /ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənɪt, ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənət/  having bad luck that you do not deserve, especially when this has a serious effect on your life, health etc:
examples: ▪ Some of the unfortunate victims were trapped inside the building for over 12 hours.
be unfortunate (enough) to do something
▪ He was unfortunate enough to lose his job just after his wife had a baby.

children.name: misfortune
children.definition: . have the  to do something/have the misfortune of doing something/hæv ðə mɪsˌfɔːʳtʃən tə ˈduː something, hæv ðə mɪsˌfɔːʳtʃən əv ˈduːɪŋ something/  formal to be unlucky on a particular occasion, especially when this results in something very unpleasant happening to you:
examples: ▪ Bowman had the misfortune of being sent to the area where there was heavy fighting.
▪ Women who have the misfortune to be involved with violent men often think it’s their own fault.

children.name: have bad luck
children.definition: /hæv ˌbæd ˈlʌk/  to be unlucky, especially in a way that affects one particular part of your life:
examples: ▪ Why do we always have such bad luck when it comes to hiring suitable workers?
have bad luck with
▪ Our kids have had very bad luck with their teachers recently.
have the bad luck to do something
▪ He had the bad luck to upset the boss’s wife at the party.

children.name: be out of luck
children.definition: /biː ˌaʊt əv ˈlʌk/  to be prevented by bad luck from doing something that you want to do, for example going somewhere, buying something, or seeing someone:
examples: ▪ I’m afraid you’re out of luck. The director has already left for the day.
▪ It looks like we’re out of luck - all the hotels are full.

children.name: a run of bad luck U
children.definition: a run of bad luck/ə ˌrʌn əv ˌbæd ˈlʌk/  a period of time during which a lot of bad things happen to you one after the other:
examples: ▪ Mimi’s had a terrible run of bad luck this year, what with the car accident and her boyfriend leaving her.
▪ Despite the Giant’s current run of bad luck, fans are still showing up for the games.

children.name: it’s not my day U
children.definition: it’s one of those days/it’s not my day/ɪts ˌwʌn əv ðəʊz ˈdeɪz, ɪts ˌnɒt maɪ ˈdeɪ/ spoken say this when a lot of bad things have happened to you that day:
examples: ▪ I just want to go home, take a bath, and go to bed - it’s been one of those days
.▪ First I missed the bus, then I spilled coffee on myself, and now my computer is frozen - it’s just not my day.

children.name: wrong place at the wrong time U
children.definition: be in the wrong place at the wrong time/biː ɪn ðə ˌrɒŋ ˌpleɪs ət ðə ˌrɒŋ ˈtaɪmǁ-ˌrɔːŋ-/  to have something bad happen to you by chance:
examples: ▪ The driver was drunk and hit her as she was crossing the road. She was just in the wrong place at the wrong time.

children.name: unlucky
children.definition: /ʌnˈlʌki/  anunluckyperson often has bad things happen to them or things often go wrong by chance for them, not because of bad planning, stupidity, or carelessness:
examples: ▪ I don’t believe anyone is born lucky or unlucky - life is what you make it.
▪ Val’s one of the unluckiest people I know - on Monday her car was stolen and the day after she fell and broke her arm.
unlucky with
▪ He seems to be very unlucky with cars - every time he buys one it always has something wrong with it.
unlucky in love
▪ I’ve never had a girlfriend more than a couple of months - I guess I’m just unlucky in love.

children.name: with my luck U
children.definition: with my luck/wɪð ˈmaɪ lʌk/  spoken say with my luck when you think something bad is going to happen to you, and you are not surprised because you think you are an unlucky person:
examples: ▪ With my luck all the tickets will be sold by the time we get there.
▪ I thought about buying a gun, but then I thought, with my luck, I’d probably end up shooting myself by accident.

children.name: just my luck
children.definition: /ˌdʒʌst maɪ ˈlʌk/  spoken say just my luck when something bad has happened to you and you are not surprised because you think you are an unlucky person:
examples: ▪ Married, is he? Just my luck
.▪ Just my luck! The one vacation I take all year, and I have to get sick.

children.name: jinxed
children.definition: be /be a jinx /biː ˈdʒɪŋkst, biː ə ˈdʒɪŋks/  to be very unlucky, so that everything you do or get involved in seems to go wrong, often in a way that affects other people too:
examples: ▪ This is the fifth company she’s worked for that’s gone bankrupt - she’s jinxed.
▪ The way the team kept losing, I was beginning to think I was some kind of a jinx.

children.name: unlucky
children.definition: /ʌnˈlʌki/  an unlucky event happens simply because of bad luck, not because of bad planning, carelessness, stupidity etc:
examples: không may mắn
▪ The car in front braked suddenly and I went straight into it - it was just unlucky.
it is unlucky (for somebody) that
▪ It was unlucky for Steve that the teacher walked in just at that moment.
unluckily[adverb]
▪ Unluckily for us, Melissa had overheard everything we said.

children.name: unfortunate
children.definition: /ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənɪt, ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənət/  unlucky - use this especially about something that causes a lot of harm or problems.Unfortunateis more formal thanunlucky:
examples: ▪ Quarterback Brady Anderson was injured in an unfortunate collision with one of his team-mates.
▪ The mix-up was the result of a set of unfortunate circumstances.
it is unfortunate (for somebody) that
▪ It was very unfortunate that someone ended up getting hurt.
unfortunately/ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənɪtli, ʌnˈfɔːʳtʃənətli/ [adverb] because of bad luck - use this when something annoying, unpleasant, or dangerous happens as a result of bad luck:
thật không may mắn
▪ I would have been here an hour ago, but unfortunately I missed the train.
unfortunately for somebody
▪ They finally cut down those old trees on our street, but unfortunately for us one of them fell on our car.

children.name: as bad luck would have it U
children.definition: as bad luck would have it/əz ˌbæd lʌk wʊd ˈhæv ɪt/  useas badorill luck would haveitwhen you are describing something unlucky that happened to you as part of a series of events, and that caused you disappointment, inconvenience etc
examples: ▪ We saw some really amazing things, but as ill luck would have it, I’d forgotten my camera
.▪ As bad luck would have it, there was a thick fog the next day and our flight was delayed.

children.name: bad luck
children.definition: be /biː ˌbæd ˈlʌk/  to happen as a result of bad luck, especially when something bad happens to you that is not your fault:
examples: ▪ His medical condition isn’t his fault - it’s just bad luck.
it is bad luck (for somebody) that
▪ It’s bad luck for her that they decided to shut down the company right after she started working there.

children.name: jinx
children.definition: there is a  on something/something is jinxed /ðeər ɪz ə ˈdʒɪŋks ɒn something, something ɪz ˈdʒɪŋkst/ if you say thatthere is a jinxon a plan, occasion etc or that itis jinxed, a lot of things go wrong with it without any reason and you think it is because of bad luck:
examples: ▪ Three people have quit, we’ve had computer problems, and now the heating has broken down. There must be a jinx on this office.
▪ It’s pouring with rain and the flowers haven’t arrived - Lynne’s convinced the whole wedding is jinxed.

children.name: bad luck
children.definition: /ˌbæd ˈlʌk/  the way that bad things happen to someone by chance, not because of bad planning, carelessness, stupidity etc: sụ không may mắn
examples: ▪ She seems to have nothing but bad luck when it comes to men.
▪ Talk about bad luck! Last night Ray’s car was broken into for the second time this month.

children.name: misfortune
children.definition: formal bad luck, especially when this results in someone having great difficulties in their life, for example being very poor, having a serious accident etc: họa,
examples: ▪ It was impossible not to feel sympathy for the family’s misfortune.
▪ Her misfortunes worsened this year, when her company eliminated her position and she lost her job.

children.name: be just as well
children.definition: (mainly UKbe as well)
examples: to be a good thing to do, or to be a lucky thing to happen or be done
_It's just as well you're not here
- you wouldn't like the noise.
_He left at three, which was just as well or he'd have missed the train.
_Itwouldbe as well to check the small print.

children.name: happily
children.definition: adverbLUCKY
examples: having a good or lucky result
_Happily, the weather remained fine throughout the afternoon.

children.name: tough
children.definition: adjectiveUNLUCKY
examples: informalunlucky
_"I've been told I've got to work late today because I'm very behind on my work." "Oh,
toughluck!"/UK"Oh, that's a bit tough!"
_It's toughonGeoff that he's going to miss the party.
